statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Arkansas 62, Georgia 47
article.story: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. (AP) -- Arkansas forward Jonathon Modica didn't dwell long on Wednesday's 62-47 win over Georgia, not even on reaching the thousand-point threshold as a Razorback. "We're trying to take steps forward to get to the NCAAs," Modica said after the victory. "We'll use the next couple days to prepare ourselves for LSU." Arkansas needed to keep its winning ways going against the SEC's weakest team if it had any hopes of an NCAA Tournament berth. Late in the first half Wednesday, they got on track to do that. With 2:05 left before intermission, the Razorbacks (16-7, 4-6 SEC) broke a 21-all tie with Georgia (7-13, 1-9) and never looked back, winning 62-47. The win provided Arkansas with its first back-to-back SEC victories of the season, and their first consecutive victories since Jan. 5, when the Razorbacks' non-conference record stood at 15-1. "We felt the schedule was turning more in our favor, although there are no easy games," Arkansas coach Stan Heath said after the game. "We just want to get us back to that .500 mark (in the SEC) at least." Freshman center Darian Townes caught fire in the second half Wednesday and scored 17 points to lead Arkansas, but the night really belonged to Modica. After getting his first start in 16 games Saturday against Mississippi, Modica stayed in the starting five and responded with 14 points. His spectacular alley-oop jam with 13:15 to go made him the 27th Razorback to surpass 1,000 career points. Breaking that barrier "means a whole lot to me, because my whole life I wanted to a Razorback," Modica said. The LSU game Saturday at Fayetteville looms large for Arkansas in part because of a heartbreaking, 66-63 overtime loss to the Tigers on Jan. 19. A last-second shot in that game by Arkansas guard Michael Jones first showed on the scoreboard as a 3-pointer. That would have given the Razorbacks their first road win in nearly two years. But after officials reviewed tape, they took a point off the scoreboard and called it a two. "We've got to do the job in conference because we're behind the 8-ball there," Heath said. The NCAAs "are not out of the question, but I can do the math. It'll be tough." A young Georgia team, with nine freshmen on its roster, continued its offensive struggles, although it outshot Arkansas from the field in the first half, 47.4 percent to 45.8 percent. The loss was the 10th in the last 11 games for the Bulldogs, who were led Wednesday night by Channing Toney's 21 points and 12 from Sundiata Gaines. No other Georgia player scored more than 6. The Razorbacks struggled when Modica went to the bench. His replacement, Dontell Jefferson, turned the ball over three times in his first three minutes running the offense, during which time Georgia erased a five point deficit. The Bulldogs kept the Razorbacks off-balance with a box-in-one defense on leading Arkansas scorer Ronnie Brewer, whose 15 points Wednesday were 1.3 off his season average. Georgia entered the game being outrebounded by 9.9 a game, but outboarded Arkansas 12-10 in the first half. But Georgia coach Dennis Felton said the box-in-one hurt his team on the glass in the second half and Arkansas finished with a 27-25 rebound advantage. "We didn't rebound well enough out of it and that's the way they started scoring -- on second shots," Felton said. Big man Townes started his 10-point second half with two offensive rebounds. Georgia was without leading scorer Levi Stukes, who sprained his ankle Jan. 15. The Bulldogs were forced to play walk-on point guard Kevin Brophy for the whole 40 minutes.
